Package com.github.tommyettinger.cringe

Class PointSequence.Halton6

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.cringe.PointSequence<Vector6>
com.github.tommyettinger.cringe.PointSequence.Halton6
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Json.Serializable, Externalizable, Serializable, Iterable<Vector6>, Iterator<Vector6>
Enclosing class:
PointSequence<V extends com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector<V>>
public static class PointSequence.Halton6 extends PointSequence<Vector6>
A very simple Iterator or Iterable over Vector6 items, this produces Vector6 points that won't overlap or be especially close to each other for a long time by using a 6D Halton Sequence. If given no constructor arguments, this uses a base of 2 for x, 3 for y, 5 for z, 7 for w, 11 for u, and 13 for v. You can specify the bases yourself (as long as they share no common factors). If you want to resume the sequence, you need only the index this was on when you want to resume it, as well as possibly the baseX, baseY, baseZ, baseW, baseU, and baseV if those differ, and can call resume(int, int, int, int, int, int, int). All Vector6 items this produces will be (and generally, those it is given should be) in the 0.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive) range. This allocates a new Vector6 every time you call next(). You can also use nextInto(Vector6) to fill an existing Vector6 with what would otherwise be allocated by next().
This can be serialized out-of-the-box with libGDX Json or Apache Fury, as well as anything else that understands the Externalizable interface.
See Also:

  • Constructor Details

    • Halton6

      public Halton6()
      Uses base (2,3,5,7,11,13) and starts at index 0.

    • Halton6

      public Halton6(int xBase, int yBase, int zBase, int wBase, int uBase, int vBase)
      Uses the given bases, which should be "relatively prime" (meaning they shouldn't share any common factors). Using different (small) prime numbers for xBase, yBase, zBase, wBase, uBase, and vBase is a good idea.
      Parameters:
      xBase - base for x, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      yBase - base for y, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      zBase - base for z, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      wBase - base for w, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      uBase - base for u, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      vBase - base for v, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)

    • Halton6

      public Halton6(int xBase, int yBase, int zBase, int wBase, int uBase, int vBase, int index)
      Uses the given bases, which should be "relatively prime" (meaning they shouldn't share any common factors). Using different (small) prime numbers for xBase, yBase, zBase, wBase, uBase, and vBase is a good idea.
      Parameters:
      xBase - base for x, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      yBase - base for y, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      zBase - base for z, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      wBase - base for w, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      uBase - base for u, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      vBase - base for v, must not share any common factors with other bases (use a prime)
      index - which (usually small) positive index to start at; often starts at 0

    • nextInto

      public Vector6 nextInto(Vector6 into)
      Sets the x,y,z,w,u,v of into to the x,y,z,w,u,v of the next item in this Halton sequence, and advances the sequence. Does not allocate. Modifies into in-place.
      Specified by:
      nextInto in class PointSequence<Vector6>
      Parameters:
      into - will be overwritten with new values, modified in-place
      Returns:
      into, after modifications
